'''''Amanita parcivolvata''''' is a [[fungus]] native to western North America from Arizona to Oregon and eastward to Kansas. One specimen has been described in Argentina, though it may have been imported with soil. Unlike most Amanita species, it doesn't appear to need a [[mycorrhiza]]l host and has been found in areas with no potential for a host, such as open cultivated fields and deserts.<ref name=amanitaceae>{{cite web| title=Amanita prairiicola| publisher=Amanitaceae| accessdate=2017-11-15| url=http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20prairiicola}}</ref><ref name=ap>{{cite book| title=The Essential Guide to Rocky Mountain Mushrooms by Habitat| last1=Cripps| first1=Cathy L.| last2=Evenson| first2=Vera S.| last3=Kuo| first3=Michael| publisher=University of Illinois Press| year=2016| isbn=9780252039966}}</ref> The cap is white, six to twenty centimeters across, and usually flat to convex. The gills are cream to gold colored, free, crowded, and broad. The stalk is fifteen to twenty by two to four centimeters, and is also cream colored.<ref name=ap />
